ぬるぬる動くドット絵がとてもキレイな横スクローグライクアクションアクションはとても軽快で、とにかくヒットアンドアウェイ。敵の攻撃直前には頭の上にマークや攻撃範囲が出るので回避のタイミングも分かりやすいです。（簡単に出来るとは言ってない）ゲームの流れはHadesに似てて、拠点でNPCと会話・強化↔ダンジョン攻略の繰り返しです。会話はフルボイス。まだ序盤ですが、ボス戦前やダンジョンから帰ってくる度更新されるのでそこそこ文章量が多いです（RPGレベルの量ではないですけど）ですが現状日本語には未対応…悲しい…個人的に好きなところは、ゲーム全体が明るい雰囲気なところです。画面も太陽サンサン明るい！ファンタジーな拠点で陽気な会話（英語なので全容は把握出来てないけど、立ち絵も笑顔でボイスもご機嫌な感じ）をして、キレイな草原のダンジョンを探索した後、スタイリッシュかつ派手なドットの動きのボス戦。少し残念な点は、日本語無いのと中断セーブがないところです。1ゲームそこそこ長いので。それとアニメチックなドット絵・アメリカンな立ち絵・西村キヌっぽいタイトル画面とかのコンセプトアートと、どれもゲーム内で雰囲気違い過ぎない？ってところですかね…

稀なおま環によるバグだと思いますが、キャラ作成後チュートリアルでNPCに話す動作が、パッドでもキーボードでも出来ずに詰みました。海外のフォーラムに解決策があり、それで解決したので書いておきます。１、Steamライブラリでモンハンライズを右クリ、プロパティを開く。２、左の一覧からコントローラを選ぶ。３、MONSTER HUNTER RISEのオーバーライドの欄で【Steam入力を無効にする】を選択追記前文には全く関係無いですが、VRModがとても良いです。まだアルファ版ですが、モンハンの世界にどっぷり浸かれます。https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2717743224https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2717743279

陰キャコミュ障でよく叫び声が汚い声の主人公が、面倒なイケメン2人にプロデュースされ、ファッションモデルを目指す乙女ゲー。おま国パッチでR-18要素解禁、MangaGamer公式でもパッチはDL可能（串かVPNは必要）中身は9割ギャグで、主人公とイケメンその1がボケ、イケメンその2がツッコミで、男女お互い振り回しつつワイワイやっていく感じです。長身黒髪ツリ目主人公ちゃんがとにかくかわいいです、汚い叫び声が特に好き。ただ乙女ゲーとしてはギャグ要素が強すぎて、甘いセリフなど言われてもあんまりときめかないかな…それだけギャグが面白いんですけどね！ちなみに日本語はボイスのみでテキストはすべて英語https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1812852165

2000円以下でフルトラ体験 Kinect・PSeyeやMove・WiiリモコンやJoycon等、3社夢の共演で様々な外部装置を活用してフルトラを体験できるツール。トラッカーを使うより格安ではありますが、色々使うのでセッティングがかなり面倒かつ不安定なツールでした。（相当頑張ってもフルトラ自体も体験レベル）しかし最新のアプデでまだベータ版ですがWebカメラ一つでお手軽にフルトラが体験 出来るツールになりました！Quest2（VDで接続）でやりましたが、Index等ほぼすべてのVRに対応しているはず。Webカメラを持っていなくても、iVCamやIriun WebcamなどスマホをWebカメラにするソフトを使えばOKあくまで体験レベルなので、素早い動きはついていかなかったり、カメラでの平面的な動きしか認識せずY軸の動き、例えば足の前後キックや座る動作はほぼ認識しなかったり（でも腰のひねりは認識します、すごい！）とトラッカーには到底及びませんが…でも体験してみる価値はあると思います。始めてVRChatをプレイし、鏡で自分を見て自分がアバターに成り代わった感動を、腰をひねらせたり足も動くようになってまた味わえますので！これくらいの動きならすんなり認識します。ヨシ！https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2638346344以下は蛇足かもしれませんがよろしければ実はこのソフト4年程前から外部サイトでのみ販売していたツールでしたが、最近Steamに完全移行したツールです。 以前のバージョンはアプデ止まっていて使っていても通知とか一切無かったので気づくまで時間かかった 以前買っていた人はDriver4公式サイトでログイン後、連絡すればSteamキーが貰えるのでチェックを。私の場合連絡後１週間程度でキーが来た記憶があります。ちなみにWebカメラ対応前、私はKinect+Joyconでフルトラをしていました。KinectはWebカメラより素早い動きを認識しやすいという利点はありましたが、トラッキング等の前準備がかなり面倒で、腰や足首のひねりはほぼ認識しないという欠点もあります。しかしひねりの方は解決する手段がありそれがJoyconです。PSMoveやWiiリモコン（初期型のみでモーションプラス内蔵の新型は非対応）も未体験ですが対応している模様。Joyconなどでどうやって認識するかというと、内蔵のジャイロ機能で感知してひねりを感知してくれます。これがすごくて、ダンスなど激しい動きも結構認識してくれます。参考に数年前の動画を。腰と左足にJoyconをつけてますが、数が足りず右足にはつけていませんが…https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2076677085
チュートリアルをやってCPU戦を終え、丁寧な翻訳や日本語吹き替えに感動し、理解を超えた超新時代的で斬新なゲーム性に胸踊らせながら対人戦に突入。10分待ってもマッチングせず、「タイムワープ系ターン制マルチプレイ戦闘ストラテジーFPS」とは一体何なのか理解出来ずに終わりました。
言語を英語にするとフレンドに招待が送れるようになりますゲーム自体はハイパースケープを思い出す内容でした水に触れた瞬間サメで即死するのが面白かったです

マルチ対応手術ゲーフレンドと二人でプレイ（フレンドはGamePass版）で序盤だけやりましたが、マルチ部分がかなり不安定です。フレンドリストが表示されなかったり、パーティに参加したら無限ロードに入ったり。手術が始まってしまえば問題ないのですが、現状そこまで辿り着くのが大変でレビューやフォーラムもその報告で溢れています。また手術クリア後には確定でブラックアウトし、Escで毎回ロビーに必要があります。結構な死にゲーなので即リプレイ出来ないのはかなり面倒です…最高ランク目指すとカドゥケウス並のミスは許されないガチガチの難易度になるので手術自体は面白いです。２人で分担して１人がノコギリで患部を切断してる間にもう１人が止血剤打ったり必要な道具揃えたりとやることが多いので、常にわちゃわちゃしてます。わちゃわちゃしてる結果、プレイヤー同士の衝突が多発し、ノコギリが滑って患者の首が飛んだり、移植用の心臓が紛失して探すはめになったり、笑えるハプニングが多発してとても楽しいです。VC推奨！野良マッチングも一応ありましたがマッチングしなかったので詳細は不明です。不安定でマルチがプレイ出来ない可能性があるので手放しにはおすすめ出来ませんが、ゲーム自体は面白いのでとりあえずおすすめに。

ずっと気になっていたゲームでアーリー抜けたみたいなので購入。正式リリース後にレビューが賛否両論までガクッと落ちてたので大丈夫か心配になりましたが、Parsecを使って3人でリモートプレイでまだ序盤ですが今の所バグ等にも遭遇せず、まともに楽しめています。ソロプレイにも対応しており、BOT２人と一緒に冒険できます、プレイヤー２人+BOT１も可能。ソロプレイは序盤を少ししかやっていませんが、AIはかなり賢いように感じました、少なくとも初回プレイの私よりは遥かに頼りになる！ゲーム内容については他の方のレビュー通りで、タンク・ダメージ・サポートの三役でプレイでプレイするベルトスクロールアクションです。皆役割が違うので協力してる感がかなりあって楽しいです。難易度は結構高めだと個人的には感じました、敵の攻撃がめっちゃ痛いのにサポートの回復には回数制限があってギリギリの戦いを強いられます。賛否両論まで落ちた理由としては、海外のレビューを見る限り・クラッシュする・オンラインプレイが不安定などが多かったですが、クラッシュに関してはチュートリアルでほぼ確定でクラッシュします。 流石に酷すぎる 一応チュートリアルはスキップ可能で、スキップ以降の本編では今の所クラッシュには遭遇していません。チュートリアルやってなくても操作もシステムも単純なので別にプレイに問題ありませんでした。オンラインプレイはマッチングしなかったのでどうなのか分かりません…現状Parsecでのリモートプレイでやるなら大丈夫かなって感じです。Steam Remote Play Togetherには現在未対応になっているので注意！開発者曰くSteam側にバグがあるらしく対応はまだ未定のようです。https://steamcommunity.com/app/1263070/discussions/4/3057365873435311042/

梅原裕一郎目当てにやりましたネコぱら本編は未プレイです エロゲーって事だけは知ってる １時間程でセージ兄さんのEDに行けました共通ルート終了後4人から１人キャラ選択してそのキャラのルート・EDといった感じキャラ選び以外選択肢は一切ありませんでした、シンプルイズベスト感想としては フルボイスでイケメンで安易なハーレムサイコー って感じでした立ち絵も表情も豊富、スチルも各キャラ2枚づつありストーリーは最初から高感度MAXのネコミミイケメン達に猛アタックされるだけですがネコなんでね、理由なく好かれても別にいいですよね。無料なんでとりあえずやってみましょう！スマホ版もありますよ！個人的にこの世界のネコがどういう存在なのか気になったのでライブラリにあったネコぱら本編もいつかプレイしようと思いましたhttps://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2548476325

とても面白い！でも個人的に不満点も PV通りの罠だらけのダンジョンを走ってムチで飛んでゴール目指すゲームマルチ要素は非同期のゴーストのみってどうなの？って思っていましたが、周りのゴーストは全員ダンジョンクリア出来ずに敗北した死者のみ、つまりゴールまで行けば全員に勝利出来るというステキなシステム。 不満点 ・ダンジョンを１層クリアする度に加護（バフや回復等）を二択から一つ購入出来るのですが、その加護の当たり外れが大きすぎる。ローグライクゲーなのでその時のアイテムドロップなどで難易度が激変するのは当然なんですが、二段ジャンプや空中浮遊、ムチ延長の加護が別ゲーになるレベルで強力すぎるのに、それ以外の加護が残念すぎます。加護の種類も大体10個くらいで内3つが当たり、その他はほぼハズレです。入手出来る数も限られているので序盤でハズレ引いたらリセットしたくなります。・高所から着地する際に受け身を取らないとダメージを食らうのですが、その受け身のローリングで画面が一回転します。めっちゃ酔います。ダンジョン一つ制覇するまでやりましたが、達成感の後に頭痛が襲ってきましたhttps://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2523878426↑こんな感じに着地するたびに世界一周不満な部分もありますが良い加護引いて気持ちいい操作感で他の死者を尻目にダンジョンをかけぬけるのは夢中になれて楽しいのでおすすめにアーリーでも基礎的な部分はしっかりしてるのでアプデに期待#ダンジョン制覇用攻略メモ・同じ銅像からでも何度も買い物可能買い物後ちょっと待てばまた話しかけることが出来ます１層攻略後とかは２回分のお金が溜まってることがあるのでまとめ買いしましょう・おすすめ加護はロングウィップ・ダブルジャンプ・ウイング３回くらい買い物終えてこれらが一つも出なかったら最深層まで目指さず途中帰宅もしくはリタイアしたくなるくらいの強力な加護ですちなみにしゃがみジャンプが高く飛べるようになる加護は単体では微妙ですが、ダブルジャンプと合わせるとこんな感じに化けます。https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2525671929単体では走りながらジャンプが出来ないため、垂直にしか大ジャンプが出来ませんが、二段目のジャンブの際にしゃがみジャンプをすると慣性をつけて大ジャンプが出来ます、ダンジョンをかけぬけろ！

A mythical boredom…When I was skimming through the upcoming releases, Frozenheim immediately caught my eye due to its promising premise of developing your own Norse colonies, which was supposed to be spiced up by the inclusion of themes from their folklore. Throw in some ground and naval combat, as well as a bit of exploration, and you have a solid foundation for a Nordic-themed city-builder; hence, I was naturally excited to give it a go.Unfortunately, my dissatisfaction appeared swiftly, partially because of the questionable marketing on the Store Page. While I understand that I should not overdo it with my assumptions, I still expected to play a proper city builder, as the lovely “rich settlement management” catchphrase promoted. Alas, instead I got a game filled with subpar combat-oriented content that became repetitive during the very first campaign, yet I had to endure through four more.For sure, the price of seventeen euros and the apparent lack of resources within the studio will not guarantee the qualities of triple-A titles. However, in such a case, Frozenheim should have leaned in one and only direction, either focusing on settlement management or on more complex combat. Instead, it fails at both aspects, delivering a half-baked, tiresome experience. Because apart from the gameplay loop, there is nothing else worth elaborating on: the narrative exists just so the various clans could fight with each other, and you can forget about some philosophical or artistic themes right away. Not that their omittance would be a negative per se, but since the gameplay is in the state it is, then such parts could help it to become more bearable to play.Let us elaborate on the abovementioned issues then, shall we? The management of your colony has the foundations you would expect: you construct buildings that gather various resources, such as food, wood, stone and more; apart from that, there are craftspeople and, of course, military-oriented structures. Yet, there is no variety whatsoever! For example, food counts as the same resource no matter whether your villagers go fishing, hunt deers or harvest wheat. Where is the promised “rich settlement management” that would influence the happiness or health of my people based on the variety of meals? That is saddening, especially since jarls even fought over these from time to time.Truthfully, the complexity is just not there. Again, that would not be a problem if the game would not market itself as something it is not, leaving me with these ambivalent thoughts. The only management aspect you will find here is assigning villagers to their respective workplaces; even their happiness level, required for getting access to higher-tier buildings, is not complex at all. I would even dare to say that I did not have to focus on maintaining it, as it increased on its own anyway. Nevertheless, that does not mean that the mechanics do not work — they do in their simplistic way; there is just not much depth in it.The combat is nothing to write home about either. There are only a few types of units, ranging from regular axemen to armoured shieldbearers, as well as archers and spearmen, operating on the classic rock-paper-scissors principle. Each has some ability, such as stunning opponents for spearmen or higher precision for ranged units, disabling the friendly fire for a few seconds. For a so-called city-builder title, it is a simple yet effective system. Unfortunately, the actual encounters are not enjoyable, mainly due to the semi-broken responsiveness of units. They tend to not follow your lawful orders, rushing to the nearest enemy despite me clicking like crazy and so on. Perhaps they were deceived by Loki? Who knows.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2838272151Moreover, the artificial intelligence behaves feebly-mindedly, being capable of escapades like rushing towards your army just to suddenly retreat and then rush back at you. Thus, it is not really challenging to deal with them. It can be annoying at times; that is, however, due to the campaigns’ scripts, as they tend to spawn a bunch of enemy units at the most random, inconvenient place possible just to slow you down. To give an example, I destroyed a supportive base of the near village, so I would not get flanked. Nevertheless, the game infinitely spawned up to three units there, forcing me to go around and launch my assault elsewhere, as they were not smart enough to follow me nor defend their home. Such an artificial way to increase the difficulty is not exactly challenging nor enjoyable; it just horrendously prolongs my playtime.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2838270962Apart from that, there is a bit of exploration, allowing you to find some stashes scattered around the map, as well as barbaric camps or animal lairs to clear; all of that rewarding you with bonus resources for your lovely colony. An occasional side quest is present to spice things up a bit, too. It is not much, but it is sufficient enough for such a title, and your opponents tend to interact with these too, which might lead to interesting situations at times.Sometimes you have to leave the ground and set sails, which surely is an intriguing addition. Regrettably, the control of naval units is quite clunky – the fights are even worse – so I mostly ignored them unless it was mandatory for finishing the mission. I mean, it is kinda hilarious to purposefully avoid the naval aspect in a Norse-oriented title, but it is what it is, eh? Artificial intelligence is even more annoying during these encounters, as it constantly tends to flee from you unless it has a massive advantage.You will engage in all of that both in the campaign and other scenarios, such as skirmishes or modes related purely to the settlement management. Sadly, despite the different objectives, it all felt kinda same to me, mainly due to the lack of variety. Even the playable clans are not that diverse, only differing in some minor abilities and upgrades, so even some variety between the factions is rather non-existent.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2838274395While expected, the audiovisual aspect is a bit underwhelming, though I would not call its visuals ugly at all, and after a while, I started adoring them for being at least quite colourful, as the scenery changes based on the current season. However, the way some people look is just not Norse-like, but rather a wanna-be take on mainstream Vikings, which is a shame. Lastly, the audio is subpar, filled with repetitive sounds and a lacklustre soundtrack.Overall, I truly cannot recommend Frozenheim, as it feels like a weird mishmash that tries to do everything but fails at being at least mediocre in its respective aspects. That is saddening, especially because of its exciting premise. Alas, after the introductory two or three hours, I basically saw everything the game had to offer and then just proceeded to sink more time in its repetitive gameplay loop. I can only hope that the potential sequel or another title will be much, much better.PC Specs and PerformanceI played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 30-60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. The framerate was dropping quite randomly, which was a bit annoying, whilst still playable due to it being a slow-ish strategy title.  AcknowledgementThis game was provided for review purposes by the developers. Thank you!Curator linkTo see the peak of reviewing, visit Summit Reviews for more reviews from me and my collegues.If you wish to see purely my remarks, then check out Blue Lips and their Quips.

A madness indeed…Source of Madness caught my attention right away just from browsing through its Store Page, as its twisted, Lovecraftian-inspired themes looked enthralling enough, making me want to give it a go. While I am not a rogue-lite enthusiast per se, I adore playing them from time to time; thus, this seemed like a perfect opportunity to satisfy my thirst for such a subgenre.The start was promising, and I thoroughly enjoyed the initial two or three hours. Moreover, the visual presentation of the opening locations hooked me; galavanting through the pompous yet dilapidated temple of your fellow acolytes felt strangely engrossing, whereas hopping near a lake that seemed to be hiding its horrors underneath the calm surface was a bit haunting. These parts work well, managing to create an eerie, captivating atmosphere. However, it does not last long, as the latter areas are lacklustre: a bland, uninteresting combination of generic environments like deep caves or dark forests. Additionally, the audio is underwhelming, presenting a barely noticeable soundtrack and repetitive sound effects that are rather irritating to your lovely ears after a while.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832258073Nevertheless, these audiovisual shortcomings are just a minor issue compared to the half-baked mess that this title is as a whole. Sure, it has an intriguing premise and ideas that perhaps sound good on paper, but its implementation is horrendous at best, and a bunch of balance inconsistencies and glitches do not make it better. Due to that, its simplistic and repetitive gameplay loop – where your one and only goal is to get to the end of the level, fighting with tons of monsters in the process – becomes rather frustrating to experience.Source of Madness tries to turn this mundane approach into an exciting one by focusing on magically-oriented combat and randomised algorithms that influence every bit of the game, whether it is the design of environments, items dropped from foes or chests, as well as enemies’ appearance and abilities.Thus, instead of wielding ordinary swords, spears or bows, you have rings and supportive items at your disposal that grant you spells, such as unleashing a volley of arcane shots, stunning lighting, poisonous clouds and much more. Yet, these abilities are highly unbalanced, making me feel like I am either obliterating everything in my way or just merely scratching my foes—as if there was no middle ground. Additionally, most boss fights are easier to deal with when you have the right tools. Then, neither of that is enjoyable since you rely on randomised loot than your skill.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832258395Like, running around with powerful homing missiles and explosives that obliterate everything in your way is not joyful, and neither are playthroughs that “blessed” you with poisonous clouds or firey effects that take too long to kill anything. Both are tiresome in their own way, especially when you get stuck with the said items because the found loot is worse, and even vendors do not have anything to offer. Consequently, I found myself dying unnecessarily a few times due to this system until the game decided to provide me with an overpowered spell against which enemies could not do anything. At times I died due to unreliable dashing, as sometimes it makes you stuck to an opponent or limb you previously dash through without problems, taking those crucial health points from you.Monsters’ appearance and abilities are problematic, as well, because they purely rely on the said randomised algorithm, which chooses what and how many limbs and types of attacks will they possess. Sure, their looks are unique, fulfilling the goal of presenting them as weird abominations, but that is about it. Most of the encounters feel the same, as foes will just crawl toward you, trying to hit you with a tentacle, occasionally casting spells, as well; it does not matter whether they are big or small, fast or slow—they all behave like that. As if that was not enough, their physics tends to glitch out, pushing them dozen of meters above you or even getting stuck in walls and ceilings, which especially happened with larger minibosses.The said bugs happened more often in the second and third acts, which seemed less polished compared to the first one, turning it into a half-broken experience. By the time I reached the final part, I was exhausted. There was not a single aspect that I would enjoy. My only hope was that the randomised loot would make me suffer less. Yet, the third act somehow managed to top this atrocious mess, as it forces you to go through almost a whole first act yet again; what a marvellous design decision to slightly boost the playtime.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832258705Since you might die often – it is a rogue-lite, after all – you have a chance to buy some permanent upgrades at the start of each run. These can boost the amount of found currency, increasing the chance of dropping rarer items or improving your health flasks. However, the prices are way too high, and even after finishing the game, I still had more than half the upgrades to unlock. Not that it matters much, as most of them were rather useless; I would even dare to say that some handicap the player. For example, the unlockable character classes felt worse, constantly having subpar stats and rings than the starting one. Sure, I could decide not to use them, but they filled one or two of the three starting slots.Well, that is all. It is a shame, for sure, as the premise of a mage fighting with Lovecraftian monsters sounds amazing to me; however, the implementation of strong randomised elements ruins the whole game completely, making it a tiresome mess that I sadly cannot recommend. Just avoid it.PC Specs and PerformanceI played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. While I have not encountered any performance-related issues, the game crashed during one of my playthroughs; while the main progress stayed the same, that very run was unfortunately lost. Thank you!Curator linksTo see the peak of reviewing, visit Summit Reviews for more reviews from me and my collegues.If you wish to see purely my remarks, then check out Blue Lips and their Quips.

The Force is strong with this one.A long time ago, the announcement of LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga got me excited, making it one of my most anticipated titles, but its constant delays made it clear that my galaxy’s visit is still far, far away…Yet, I remained so patient that even Yoda blissfully shivered from my accomplishment.Was it worth the wait? Absolutely.By portraying all three trilogies, The Skywalker Saga provides a coherent, entertaining storyline filled with humorous twists and quips that never become boring. Truly. Not only that it feels like a complete, parodying recreation, but it also comes up with its own jabs that even make fun of some of the decisions made in each instalment; thus, even horrendous episodes like Attack of the Clones or The Last Jedi are enjoyable. Moreover, it inspires itself by the popular Star Wars memes, which is a nice touch as it underlines its dedication to the fandom.Due to that, it caters to the fans rather than to everyone—and that is fine. Could you enjoy it without being familiar with the films? Probably, as the game still has a lot to offer, but many jokes might fly over your head at lightspeed. I am glad that it is like that, though, as it would lose part of its charm otherwise.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2823561835The way you experience the campaign is a bit different this time; it lets you galavant through the galaxy and visit numerous planets, with an occasional unique mission here and there. Thus, it feels like a thorough, delightful journey rather than a bland list of levels, making the whole adventure more satisfactory.As it is an action-adventure title – from a tighter third-person perspective this time – the usual gameplay loop revolves around exploring, platforming, hoarding all the collectables and, of course, fighting. When you are not directly following the story, you can just venture away and explore the universe on your own. However, do not expect a seamless open world; instead, it consists of a bunch of playable areas in each system. I would say it is better that way because the locations are designed with care to provide just enough content without overwhelming you.Apart from relaxing sightseeing, there are the said collectables to find; picking them up is not pointless, though, as you use them to upgrade your characters’ abilities or unlock additional, hilarious rewards, like a fierce Porg companion or baguettes that replace the lightsabers. To obtain them, you usually have to solve a simple environmental puzzle. Even though that might get a bit repetitive after a while, I did not mind it because I adored discovering new locations and trying out other iconic characters.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2823561318Speaking of those, you can unlock them, along with starships, by completing side missions. These quests often tend to deliver an even more over-the-top take on Star Wars. At one point, you might find yourself smuggling trampolines to Mustafar, ending it with a bouncy fight against Bossk, or you could be crushing down a revolt of cloned woolamanaders – who are essentially cute blue apes – on the Kamino facility. This kind of content serves as a sweet, optional stuffing that can spice up your journey.That leads us to the combat, which surprisingly has a lot of depth when compared to an average LEGO game. For sure, it is still pretty effortless, so do not expect any hardships or obstacles in your way. There are, however, several possibilities to use, as apart from mashing one button, you can engage in various combos that make encounters more fun and satisfying to observe. Whether you viciously slice through a bunch of Clones with Maul’s double-bladed lightsaber, blast everyone’s heads off with Boba Fett’s carbine rifle, or slap others as C-3PO, you know it is going to be a joyful time. And if that does not convince you, then undulating around as Mamma the Hutt, licking everyone in the process, should do so!These differences do not only influence the combat but the overall interaction with the world, as well. Where a Jedi will take advantage of their agile movement or the Force, a bounty hunter will rely on a jetpack and grappling hook; due to that, the character classes complement each other. It is a simple yet effective system that pushes you to try out more of the iconic heroes or villains.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2823561580Unfortunately, the skirmishes in space are disappointing, though serviceable for what they are. While there is a decent variety of starships to choose from, the combat lacks the complexity of the ground one. You only have one attack option, with the possibility of unleashing a homing missile, and that is it. Thus, all of these encounters are bland and uninspiring, becoming boring later on. The exceptions are a few main missions or battles with capital ships, which at least offer unique objectives that balance out the monotonous gameplay.Additionally, the absence of online cooperative play is saddening. Even though you can use Steam’s Remote Play, it is not enough, mainly because every progress made counts only for the host while your friends gain nothing. That is weird and discouraging, as you suddenly cannot use the characters and abilities you unlocked but rely purely on your friend’s ones. Also, doing all the collectables twice does not sound that appealing either.Where The Skywalker Saga beautifully shines is its audiovisual presentation. Simply put, it is top-notch. All the planets with their iconic locations are glamorous to lie your eyes on, and all the ships, even the capital ones or Death Star itself, are made purely of LEGO bricks, which nicely distinguish them from the rest of the environment. Just galavanting through the deserts of Tatooine or the city of Theed, listening to its iconic themes is heartwarming.Another nice touch is the presence of some of the original trilogy’s actors, who reprise their roles, like Anthony Daniels as C-3PO or Billy Dee Williams as Lando. You can also hear a few familiar voices from the animated The Clone Wars show. Naturally, not everyone could be present, but the attempt still shows the dedication put into this project. Moreover, the number of additional monologues and even dialogues between numerous characters is astonishing; even Darth Vader and Kylo Ren have their small talk, and at times, they might even perform an amusing animation when you let them stand in place for a while. The love and care just jump at you at every bricky corner you pass by.That would be perhaps the best summary for The Skywalker Saga.Overall, I adore this title, as it is a special experience that managed to awake an inner child in me, a kid that enjoyed watching the films over and over again. The humorous nature and relaxing gameplay make for an excellent combination. Yes, some aspects could have been a tad bit better; however, that does not take away the dozens of hours of fun I had. Thus, I can wholeheartedly recommend it to any Star Wars enthusiast.Now excuse me; I still have a few collectables to find.PC Specs and Performance I played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 35-60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. Some of those frame drops only occurred on specific locations, like Endor or D’Qar, so I assume it has to do something with the forest environment and background since other planets ran smoothly.  Acknowledgement This game was gifted to me by a dear friend of mine. Thank you!Curator link  To find the high ground of the reviewing community, check out my curator, Blue Lips and their Quips!

Knighthood reeking of gunpowder...Spending a fair amount of time in the original Age of Empires III, as well as in its respective successors on Steam, I must say that I am pretty satisfied with the way this Definitive Edition still receives a lot of additional content. It is just heartwarming to see this franchise flourish after so many years.Though it makes me happy, I still have that one grudge against these additions. Quite an important one, I might add. What would that be? Well, none of these expansions – Knights of the Mediterranean included – brought a new campaign. It is a shame, truly, especially when it is already a norm for its predecessor, Age of Empires II. Perhaps a cute little price reduction would nicely make up for such a loss, but that is rather a naïve and laughable thought in today’s world.Well then, what do Knights of the Mediterranean bring to the table?The main selling point is its two new factions – Italy and Maltese – who, at last, join the skirmishes of the early modern period, marching in with their armoured, knightly armies. Truthfully, I wanted such a thing for years, as Maltese’s enthralling presence in the base campaign always felt special. However, their unique units were always strictly assigned to you, or you could rarely recruit them. Thus, them having its own playable civilization is a tiny dream that came true.Yet when I finally got around to playing this expansion, I stuck with Italians for most of my time. How so? I had more fun fiddling with their economy, which allowed me to research technologies and raise buildings rather quickly, gaining that sweet upper hand over my foes. Due to that, our friends from the Apennine Peninsula might be a bit overpowered, but I enjoyed playing as them nonetheless. Their unique soldiers are not terrible either, as the various Papal units can absorb the damage inflicted upon their brothers in arms. And if you add range-oriented Bersaglieres to the mix, who can outrun most of the infantry, flanking and even stun them, then you know you have a prominent combination in your hands.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2822598950Maltese, however, seems to focus more on the defensive approach; they can build stationary cannons or ammunition depots that can serve as an explosive trap. Moreover, their troops receive a boost in speed and damage when they happen to be in the vicinity of allied buildings. While that is all sweet and helpful, I always had the feeling I am a bit behind others with my economy, never reaching the levels like with Italians. Nevertheless, I still enjoyed playing as them, especially during battles; their armoured musketeers are charming to lay your eyes on, mainly during volley fires.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2822599255Still, I am satisfied with both factions, as they surely bring fresh gunpowder-y air to the game.Apart from that, there is also a bunch of new European maps, adding to an already vast roaster of locations to fight in. Some of the historical ones even have a twisty victory condition. For example, in The Russo-Turkish war, you need to capture and hold the trading route for a few minutes; the twist lies with a few stationary cannons that can prove deadly to the marching army. Witnessing a bunch of pitiful troops getting obliterated is quite hilarious, though.Moreover, several royal châteaus are scattered throughout these maps, waiting for you to place your embassy there. By doing so, you will ally with a set European Royal House - such as the Habsburgs or Jagiellons - allowing you to recruit their special units and use powerful abilities, like revealing the location of enemy buildings or boosting the effectiveness of villagers. That all can surely change the pace of the match a bit, but it is not crucial in order to win it.What surprised me the most, however, was the so-called Tycoon mode, which focuses on developing a strong economy, where you obtain victory points based on your economical successes. While it is possible to attack enemies, your unit count is limited to pitiful twenty-five soldiers, and they all gradually lose their health, stopping at one health point. Sure, it is still possible to harass your foes a bit, but it can easily backfire; thus, micromanagement is more important than ever. I thought I would be bored by this mode, but due to the abovementioned aspects, it was an enjoyable experience, especially if you are tired of the regular matches.Overall, I am satisfied with the Knights of the Mediterranean expansion, as the content it delivers is enough to spice up the gameplay loop for those who lust for more content. As for me, it is the best addition to Age of Empires III so far, as the Italians clicked with me and became one of my favourite factions. Thus, I can easily recommend it, if you can overcome the saddening fact of the omitment of the campaign.PC Specs and Performance I played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 40-60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. The frame drops depend on a specific map, as it seems that some are a bit unoptimized compared to others. While it never made the game unplayable, it was still fairly noticeable.Acknowledgement This downloadable content was provided for review purposes by the publisher. Thank you!Curator linksFor more in-depth reviews both from me and my colleagues, check out Summit Reviews.If you wish to see purely my remarks, then take a look at Blue Lips and their Quips.

”It’s time to raise the black flag and start cutting throats.” – Capt. ReyesWith its yearly releases, Call of Duty became one of the most prominent first-person shooters that is, however, constantly accompanied by mixed feelings and double-edged critique. Rightfully so, I might add, as the series tends to tiptoe around, bringing just the minimum innovations and changes, thus not differing enough from its – by now familiar – roots.Yet, Infinite Warfare tries to break this stale cycle by fully venturing beyond the Earth’s exosphere, letting you visit numerous celestial bodies of our Solar System. Even though this approach finally replaces the bland semi-futuristic setting of its predecessors, it still fails to commit to this new, almost limitless potential. As if the fear or laziness hampered the willingness to take advantage of this fresh premise.The campaign suffers from that the most, and I often found myself stuck with ambivalent thoughts, not being able to decide whether to praise or scold the game for its presentation. However, claiming that I did not enjoy my time with it would be a blatant lie—it still manages to provide a thrilling, action-packed experience that other big franchises fail to recreate in such an enthralling manner.At least the start is promising.As a member of the Earth’s special forces, you drop into an icy moon of Jupiter – Europa – to seize back weapon prototypes from a militaristic Mars. You fail, though, and Martians quickly obliterate your squad and cripple the allied fleet, forcing you into guerrilla warfare. Is it a simplistic premise? For sure! Being put in the “last hope” kind of role that fights against injustice and oppression is nothing imaginative, but due to its pompous presentation, it hooked me right from the beginning.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2810469674However, the narrative and its characters dragged down my excitement soon, turning this journey into a problematic one. That is mainly a fault due to the depiction of the antagonistic Mars, along with the main villain – Admiral Kotch – portrayed by Kit Harington. He behaves like a mundane caricature with one and only motive: to destroy everything. Moreover, Kotch is obsessed with threatening you every few minutes via his never-ending speeches. It perhaps was intimidating the first time but became tiresome the ninth one. And his irresistible urge to finish every piece of monologue with “Mars aeternum.” is just a cherry on top! I guess it is a tad bit better than his “I don’t want it.” from the Game of Thrones series, but it is still kinda cringeworthy.Unfortunately, your companions are not much better, as they represent the basic military tropes. While most characters in the franchise are guilty of that too, they at least gave me a feeling of an existing comradeship before. Yet, Infinite Warfare fails at doing so, mainly because its moments, which are crucial for the character development, are presented way too early, late, or not at all. Thus, I honestly did not care about anyone or anything. I was there just to kill the baddies. That is a shame, as it certainly had the potential to deliver a more memorable experience.Despite these glaring issues, the playthrough is still satisfying; a constant flow of different environments helps with that, as galavanting on the surface of the Red Planet, floating between asteroids and spaceships’ debris, or participating in space battles always looks, sounds and feels astonishing.Moreover, the gameplay tries to reflect on these changes, either by providing new possibilities or changing the missions’ approach. Partially, at least, as the core is still the same, meaning that you will venture through a bunch of linear corridors, chaotically shooting at everything that moves, taking cover from deadly explosions and witnessing your pitiful allies dying. That is all I need, though—a simple yet captivating action. However, Infinite Warfare tries to spice things up by putting you in control of your own customisable jet, which breaks this gameplay loop a bit; in some missions, it even combines these two approaches, placing you in frenetic dogfights, followed by the boarding of the command ship. That is where this title shines the most, as such thrilling encounters do justice to the game’s setting.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2810470155All of that is done during the main missions, but you can also participate in several side ones, where you can hunt commanding officers, cripple their supplies or destroy some lonely battleships. Even though these tasks are relatively simple, they are set in new locations, so there is still something new to discover. And their biggest plus is that they will spare you from Harington’s blabbering!Your weaponry can be customised before each of these missions, but there is truly not much to do. A classic menu of assault rifles, shotguns, and such, awaits you. Not that they are boring to use, but I expected a bit more experimentation due to the futuristic setting. Sure, Infinite Warfare tries to do so at times; for example, you can use a heavy laser that literally melts your foes, or you can hack hostile robots and control them. There is even a grappling hook that is useful for a fast movement between debris in the vacuum or for performing sweet finishers on lone enemies. That is all enjoyable; it is just something that I have seen numerously in these games, so the lack of fresh ideas is a bit saddening.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2810469264At times, you can use the environment to your advantage. The infamous red barrels are naturally present but destroying a random window is a more intriguing option, as witnessing how it sucks out both air and soldiers, who proceed to suffocate, is both hilarious and satisfying.Taking all of that into account, it definitely managed to deliver the action this franchise is known for.The other aspect that Call of Duty is famous for is multiplayer. You know, those lovely sessions where dozens of kids claimed to have intercourse with your mom, followed by incomprehensible screaming, after which they suddenly drop out due to their parents setting them straight. That sounds so alluring, right? There is one tiny little problem, though—the multiplayer is dead. While you can play its game modes against artificial intelligence, it can hardly make up for competing with people. You can also hop into a zombie mode, which is playable solo, but I would not recommend it, as it was clearly designed for a squad, so it is rather unbalanced. Or I just suck. Simply put, do not buy this title for its multiplayer elements unless you have friends to play with.Overall, it took me about thirteen hours to finish it on the Veteran difficulty, fully completing all of its side content; without that, it would take me about half the time. I surely expected a bit more from Infinite Warfare, as the lack of commitment to its potential disappointed me. Nevertheless, it still delivers an honest, thrilling and enjoyable experience, so it would be unfair to give it a thumbs down.It is a good Call of Duty instalment, just not one of the best ones.PC Specs and PerformanceI played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 55-60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. A few framedrops were present, but they did not hinder my experience.Curator linkIf you can comprehend more words than  “Mars aeternum”, then feel free to check out my curator, Blue Lips and their Quips!

PAAAAAAAAAAAIIIIIIIIINNNN.Usually, I would not accept a game like this for a review, but since it was the very first offer for my new curator, I could not refuse—what if it was some hidden gem, after all? Sure, its cheap visuals are not exactly charming, but looks are deceiving at times.That was not the case here, though.At its core, it is a simple 2D platformer in which you control a lovely ghost, who has to swiftly move to the end of the level, avoiding all the deadly obstacles in its way. What an innovative experience, right? Yet, having simple gameplay would not be an issue per se if it would be enjoyable and designed well.However, that is (yet again!) not the case here.Apart from getting to the end of the map without dying, you also have to collect shiny gems. Not to get a higher score with which you could boast about to your friends, no. You have to do so to unlock more levels. However, this concept was apparently way too primitive, so the developer(s) decided that in order to progress further, you have to unlock both regular and “hardcore” variants of each mission. Thus, if you want to play level four, you need to unlock both versions of level three, along with the fourth mission. It is not possible to just play the normal ones. To add to it, the price increases with each new level, leading to a tremendously annoying grind. Atrocious.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2744125559Luckily for the players, someone in their infinite wisdom forgot to limit the number of gems you can collect in one level, meaning that you can just grind the easiest missions over and over again. Due to that, with a little patience, you can unlock everything and skip through all the content right to the end. Truly a pinnacle of design.While there was an attempt to make the gameplay a bit more diverse by including levels with worse visibility or timer, forcing you to be both careful and fast, it does not matter due to the unresponsive controls. Thus, the better approach is just to run forward & pray for the best outcome.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2744138058Moreover, I received most of the achievements within the first hour, so I thought that this was one of those titles to easily farm achievements on; however, the last one seems to be locked till I actually beat all the levels, meaning even on hardcore difficulty. If this was an intention, then I can definitely appreciate an approach to troll these souls who desperately strive to play games like that. If it is just a glitch, though, then my one and the only positive remark is irrelevant, I guess.Conclusion, conclusion… there is nothing more to talk about here. Just avoid this! Do not let this tarnish your cute profiles!PC Specs and Performance I played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. I have not encountered any problems with the performance whatsoever.AcknowledgementThis game was provided for review purposes by the developers. Thank you!Curator linkEven though this review was quite short, you will find much longer (and juicier ones!) on my curator, Blue Lips and their Quips, so feel free to check it out!

"You're better off than I thought."When Resident Evil: Village got announced, I was both enthusiastic and sceptical about it. Even though I adored its premise, I was not fond of it leaning more towards the action, as I would prefer it maintaining the frightening atmosphere from its predecessor. Yet, when I finally started playing it, I could not help to not fall in love with it. Although it is not the first-person shooter horror experience I wished for, its confidence in being its own thing managed to convince me of its qualities.Simply put, Village shines thanks to merging constant fast-paced action with straightforward yet rewarding exploration in its varied, beautiful environments, along with a cheesy narrative that is, however, saved by its charismatic antagonists. Thus, it is aware of its strong and weak aspects, balancing them well and delivering a triple-A title that might not be remembered for its complex narrative or revolutionary gameplay, but just for being a damn enjoyable addition to the series—and that is enough. Instead of bloating its players with tons of mediocre or repetitive content, it provides a few hours of honest fun. Perhaps a bit dumb one at times, for sure, but definitely worthy of my time.Why would it be dumb? Mainly for its plot. I guess one could say that it is in the series’ nature, and perhaps that is why many love it, but I still cannot fully wrap my head around it. The narrative is filled with inconsistencies, where it feels like that its characters behave like feeble-minded individuals on purpose until the story demands otherwise. Due to that, I could not bring myself to care about their problems and goals. However, once any of the villains appeared, I gladly gave them my full attention, as those engrossing (sometimes gross) encounters were the peak of this title for me.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2693929750With them comes my biggest gripe with this game, though, and that would be the fact that I would love to interact with them more. Yet, its fast-paced style does not allow that, as you are thrown into different situations every few minutes. That is a shame, as I still remember my escapades with daddy Baker from Resident Evil VII, and I missed something like that here; compared to him, the encounters presented here are short and heavily scripted.Luckily, the rest of the game makes up for it. Just the atmosphere itself is so captivating! Galavanting through an old yet beautiful castle while a snowy storm roars outside its massive walls feels both tensive and cosy. That is only one of the parts of this journey, though, as you will visit various diverse environments, where each tries to represent a different take on a horror genre, some of which truly surprised me. Yet, it would not work well without proper audio, which is, as expected in this series, of top-notch quality again. You can hear all the heavy steps, slow breathing of monsters waiting to bite into your throat—it is haunting. And the voice actors did an outstanding job in making those villains so charming, I will give them that.Then, there is the gameplay, which excels with its combination of action, exploration and a few horror elements, constantly changing between these every few minutes, creating this swift pace that did not bore me at any moment. Perhaps it could be even described as a nod to the series as a whole as if it tried to combine the best parts of its popular instalments and come up with something for everyone. Such an approach usually ends up being a disaster, but seeing how much I enjoyed playing Village—it proved me wrong in this case. Except for puzzles… those still suck. Like, c'mon, it feels as if the developers made them for a kindergarten event.While I would surely wish for having more of the terrifying parts, as I felt these were overshadowed by the other ones, I cannot say that its omittance hurts the game per se. Sure, the exploration seems to be easier now, as you are not always chased by some maniac, but it allows for delivering a bit different design approach, where you can search for more treasures and pieces of lore, and then for tons of resources and ammunition, of course. Crafting is important more than ever, as foes come at you in big numbers. Unfortunately, you cannot put items in the storage box anymore, so you have to manage your inventory and either sell or discard the unnecessary stuff. Yet, the loot scattered around looks a bit silly at times. I mean, it usually happens to lie at the most inconvenient place! Like, why does vampiric mama Dimitrescu needs four shotgun shells on her nightstand? To use them as a butt plug? Not judging, but…https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2693928447Well, at least you can kindly borrow those shells and obliterate any monster that dares to cross your way, whether it is werewolves, totally-not-zombies and… dang, that is perhaps all? Saying more would be spoilies, but the enemy variety manages to keep the gameplay fresh for the whole playthrough, so do not worry about that. The same applies to the boss fights, which usually require a bit different approach to beat them. I mean, sure, you just shoot at them, but at different parts… Eh, it is Resident Evil, do not expect much complexity.Moreover, you can shoot off weapons from your foes’ hands or even try to immobilize them by hitting their legs, which makes combat more fluid and fun. While gunplay felt a bit clunky at first, it grew on me later on because of two reasons: upgrading your firearms truly matters, and the later ones are just satisfying to shoot. Additionally, you can also use the environment up to your advantage or place mines and such, so there is room to experiment, even if only a little. The good ol’ shotgun is still the best, though!Yet, the very best thing is that you will not be alone during this journey of yours. Wait, do not panic! You will not get to escort another Ashley, who would constantly scream your name. No! Instead, you will meet someone better, sexier and smarter— I am talking about the Duke, of course, who is the most accurate depiction of the oppressed gamers™. Thus, due to his weight (his body, his choice, you intolerant monsters!), he will not follow you around, but he will help by providing information or trading with you from his cosy basement.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2693931006If the abovementioned content sounds good for you, then you can look forward to more, as once you finish your first playthrough, a so-called Content Shop unlocks, allowing you to buy new fancy weapons or even cheats, such as unlimited ammo. With these, you can josh around and show those monsters who's the boss here. Apart from that, there is Mercenaries mode, which tests your skills, both in precision and speed, in various arenas filled with aggressive enemies, and it will surely make you hate it once you fail.Overall, I managed to get about sixty hours out of Village, replaying it three times and then spending more in the Mercenaries mode. Yet, even a single playthrough, lasting for about fifteen hours, is a fair amount of time, especially considering this title’s qualities. It might not be my favourite game from 2021, but it is a damn enjoyable one.And that is what matters.PC Specs and PerformanceI played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 40-60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. There were a few framedrops here and there but nothing annoying. AcknowledgementThis game was gifted to me by a dear anonymous friend of mine. Thank you!Curator linkWhile vampires in Village do not have Blue Lips, I am sure they would still enjoy Their Quips, so follow my curator!

Nine out of ten rats agree that this is a tail worth getting your hands on!Tails of Iron, revolving around brave rats, immediately caught my interest due to its beautiful hand-drawn visuals that reminded me of some of the childhood’s books I used to read years ago, so I naturally wanted to try it out. Even though audiovisuals are not usually on my priority list when playing games, the incredible amount of details that please your senses from start to finish made me adore this title.Because of that, Tails of Iron managed to hook me from the beginning. Yet, that was not the only surprise! A familiar voice greeted me—Doug Cockle’s one, whom you might know as Geralt of Rivia from The Witcher trilogy. Doug’s lovely voice is the only one that will bless your ears, as he narrates the whole story while all of the animals only make incomprehensible noises. Then, the catchy soundtrack only underlines the audiovisual qualities, forming a charming, atmospheric experience.However, is that enough? Or is this just another eye-candy game without much else to offer?Let us start with the premise; your peaceful rat kingdom flourished until it got invaded by villainous frogs who left their scummy pond to plunder your homeland. Unfortunately, they succeeded and left it in ruins. Yet, there is a last light of hope, as our protagonist, prince Redgi, intends to claim the crown, restore the glory of his lands and seek that sweet vengeance.That is about it, as it is the classic tale of a hero gathering their strength and, along with friends, standing up to the greater evil. Sure, that is not a unique nor complex narrative, but I would say that it is just enough in this case. While there are few interesting twists here and there, I rather enjoyed the story because some of its parts were pretty wholesome, and Doug delivers them amazingly.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2622628155How does it play, though? I would describe it as a simplistic take on the Metroidvania subgenre, as you have to travel through several diverse maps, search for various items and then backtrack to use them to get rid of the obstacle that forbade you from progressing further. I said “simplistic” because the world of Tails of Iron is not exactly interconnected, as there is fast travel between the main areas. I am okay with that; however, the issue is that the game forces you to revisit the previous regions often and participate in fetch quests required for finishing the storyline. As Tails of Iron only lasts about ten hours, such an approach is a bit disappointing, as I would prefer a new additional area for those quests. At the very least, the visual representation of those locations change as you progress through the narrative, so there was at least an attempt to make it a tad bit better.On this journey of yours, you will get ambushed by numerous types of animals, whether it would be those barbaric frogs, aggressive insects or other wicked beings. The combat system is simple; you only have light and heavy attacks, plus parrying, dodging and rolling. Despite the abovementioned fairy-tale vibes, the animations are brutal yet delightful to watch, as Redgi performs various finishers on those vicious frogs or dissects the corpses of bugs for their fluid to fill up his health flask.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2622625856Thus, participating in encounters is enjoyable, especially when you fight with numerous enemy types at once, as it feels fairly challenging and satisfying to play. However, the combat system becomes problematic with some of the later boss fights, as the hitboxes related to their attacks are wonky; once you roll through them safely, while the other time you get hit. Moreover, some bosses tend to spam one type of attack, which can stunlock you, resulting in your immediate death. Even though I overall had a good time with it, these instances were annoying enough and might prove even more challenging for the newcomers to this subgenre.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2622630964You can influence the combat a bit by choosing from multiple weapons, like swords, hammers and spears; each has its own attack pattern that can prove useful in different situations. My favourite one would be the spear, as it is fast enough to deliver continuous hits before the enemy reacts properly. Additionally, ranged weapons allow you to deal with the annoying flying insect, or you can put a bit of poison on your blades. While both have their use, they are not really a competent part of the weaponry, which is a bit of shame.Apart from that, you can choose from a variety of armours and helmets: light, medium and heavy ones. Each can provide additional defence bonuses against certain enemy types, so it is worth changing them often. They also add to your weight bar, but I honestly never noticed much of a difference nor felt any disadvantage for wearing heavier armour, so I ignored it completely and used whatever I wanted. This whole system is not necessarily bad—it is just way too simple.I guess that would be all, as there is not much else to say. Tails of Iron nails it with its amazing audiovisual presentation and a simple yet wholesome story, but the gameplay drags it down, as it could have been much better. However, I cannot say I was bored at any time, so I do not mind recommending this title for what it is; perhaps it would be better to wait for a sale, though.PC Specs and PerformanceI played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. I have not experienced any issues whatsoever, so the optimization seems to be top-notch.AcknowledgementThis game was provided for review purposes by the publisher. Thank you!Curator linkHonest rats are welcome at Blue Lips and their Quips while the scummy frogs can return to their shady pond!

“The situation is FUBAR,“ said Prophet, unknowingly summarizing my whole experience with this so-called remaster.Even though the abovementioned quote might be a bit cheesy, I could not help myself because of how ironic it is. As a fan of the original Crysis from 2007, I was sceptical about this new version, especially after I heard numerous complaints when it was released a year ago on a different platform. I wanted to try it out nonetheless, though. Perhaps it got better after a few updates?Well, that certainly did not happen, hence the FUBAR quote.The original game has been removed from Steam; thus, you can now only get this subpar version, and I sincerely discourage you from doing so.Crysis Remastered is not a step forward, nor it does not at the very least stagnates like other remasters. Instead, it manages to be worse than the original game, indolently ruining already existing aspects rather than making them better or bringing some modern quality of life improvements.Thus, it was a bit hard for me to write this critique of mine. While the core of this first-person shooter remains the same, the said aspects are subpar, making my experience tiresome. Due to that, I was forcing myself to finish it, as that was not „my“ lovely Crysis anymore but rather its butchered version. And that is not a moaning of a nostalgic guy with so-called pink glasses because I have replayed and even reviewed the original a year ago, so it is still fresh in my mind.Let us get to the game itself, though. The premise of its narrative is not extraordinary nor a reason why you should play Crysis, but it is serviceable for what it is. You are supposed to rescue a bunch of scientists from North Korean claws on the Lingshan Islands. To achieve that, you have a powerful Nanosuit that enhances your combat possibilities by increasing your strength, speed or even making you invisible for a while. However, you will find out soon enough that there are some strange alien beings on this very island, and they are not exactly happy with your presence. Despite these aliens and futuristic equipment, I still find the fact that North Koreans successfully conquered a foreign piece of land as the most unrealistic one.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2616042933Nevertheless, Crysis excels with its simple yet engaging gameplay loop, which could be the remaster’s case, too, if it was not for several shortcomings. The freedom in how to approach each situation, whether by going all-in with a minigun and grenades, armoured vehicles or by silently killing enemies one by one, is still present. You can even customize the weapons by adding various attachments, such as scopes or different ammo types. However, artificial intelligence seems to be even dumber than before, as I witnessed it demonstrate brilliant tactics like observing the nearest wall or walking in circles. Moreover, it felt as if there were fewer foes, as several patrols I expected to encounter were missing during my playthrough; it seems as if they did not spawn at all. Lastly, there are some unnecessary changes, such as providing players with infinite ammunition when controlling a tank—this allows you to obliterate everything from a distance, destroying the original’s purpose of being careful and scavenging for supplies. Due to all of that, it felt significantly easier to play this remastered version even on the highest difficulty setting.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2616039541What made my experience even worse were the weird controls, as the mouse movement is not as smooth as I am used to and meddling with its settings did not solve this issue; it felt as if it was constantly fighting with me, so I could not relax and enjoy my time with it. Another problem is that some actions, like reloading and changing fire mode, are set to a single key, due to which neither of them works, and you have to rebind them from scratch to be able to use actually use them. Additionally, changing the colour of the interface swaps it only in the main menu but not in the game itself. Ah, I almost forgot… both manual and quicksaves are not implemented to this very day either. I would guess that all of these oversights happened because of porting it from an old engine used for consoles rather than using the original one.Then, there is an aspect that is completely missing—the multiplayer part. I have adored playing it years ago, as it had a bit unique take on large-scale battles, with capturing crucial points and using vehicles as the Battlefield series presents nowadays. Its inclusion could make Crysis Remastered worthy, as it would revive its community; alas, that did not happen.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2616030747As for audiovisuals, there is a massive issue with the imbalance of audio, which is mainly noticeable when firing from weapons. For example, a regular handgun’s sound almost blew off my eardrums, while a fully automatic assault rifle is barely hearable. I could forgive such inconsistencies in a small indie title but in a remastered version of a triple-A game? That is both sad and laughable; mainly, when you consider the fact that this has not been fixed for over a year by now. I guess some of the updated visuals deserve a bit of praise, but the original already looked amazing; I mean, it is Crysis after all, which started the infamous “But Can It Run Crysis?” meme.Honestly, I do not see a single reason for which I should recommend buying Crysis Remastered. The audacity to ask the owners of the original title to pay for this subpar, butchered version is beyond me. For a long-time fan of the series, it feels like a slap in the face. I would not suggest this even to newcomers, as Crysis from 2007 is much cheaper. A counter-argument could be that some people have problems with launching the original, but that only underlines my point! If someone did not bother to fix these issues over the years, they should not tell their customers: “Hey, we have finally fixed it! Just pay another fifteen euros!”. Disgusting. There are already many questionable remasters with performance problems, such as BioShock or Mafia II, but even those were at the very least provided for free—that does not mean we cannot criticize them, but at the very least they do not present themselves as the second coming of Jesus when their state is worse than his during the crucifixion.PC Specs and PerformanceI played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 25-60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. Changing graphical options down to medium or even lowest did not influence my framerate. Moreover, Motion Blur kept turning itself on every single time.AcknowledgementThis game was provided for review purposes by the publisher via Reviewers’ Paradise, a place that connects both developers and reviewers.Curator linkRemember that Blue Lips Never Lie! Thus, follow my curator, Blue Lips and their Quips, to find more honest yet humorous reviews!

Much have I suffered, waited long and bored, for the AI to finish its turns. And playing it was no better – the borefest kept going on!This phrase from Homer I dared to butcher perfectly summarizes my time with A Total War Saga: TROY, which makes me sad, as this instalment, set in the Bronze Age, had the potential to bring a bit of fresh air into this franchise.Alas, that did not happen.While one of the main selling points, the “Truth Behind the Myth” campaign mode, has an interesting premise of interpreting both historical and mythological aspects in a semi-realistic way, it does not fully commit to them, resulting in a weird, bland mishmash. Instead of taking advantage of its setting, it delivers half-baked mechanics and simplifies, even omits at times, well-functioning aspects from its predecessors, presenting a mediocre turn-based strategy experience at best.Let us start from the beginning, though. I decided to start my campaign in the said mode as the kingdom of Ithaca, ruled by a cunning Odysseus. We know that he is cunning because he repeats it every single time you click on him instead of, you know, having some unique tactics or mechanics that would do justice to his character and change the classic Total War formula a bit. Nevertheless, I started slowly expanding and conquered a few neighbouring factions, who were apparently surprised by my cunning strategy of attacking their settlements by sending armies via the main road.With enough cities, you can decide whether they will focus on industry, agriculture or military by constructing various buildings that either provide resources and bonuses for its region or allow you to recruit units and generals for your armies. There are also special agents who can, for example, poison the supplies of your foes or boost your production. However, my faction has an illogical disadvantage, as it cannot build anything in territories that do not have access to the sea. Barracks or farms on an archipelago? Sure! In a vast, inland region? Even our cunning Odysseus cannot figure out how to do so.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612952768For all of that, you will need enough resources: food, stone, wood, bronze and gold. While I adore this change, as it is more interesting than having a singular currency for everything, it becomes unbalanced after a few hours, as you will have tons of them anyway. I thought I would have to carefully decide whether to use bronze for an armoured unit or some buildings, but I could do both and much more. Having five different resources also means that other factions will keep sending you several trade requests per turn, which is pretty annoying. Moreover, it seems that opposing factions do not play by these rules, as they always recruited a lot of elite soldiers despite lacking the materials, making this mechanic purposeless.I am also disappointed by the outdated diplomacy system, in which factions ignore most of the options, following only the simplistic loop of sending you trade requests, declaring war and pleading for peace over and over again. While this might be serviceable in the Total War: WARHAMMER franchise, as that compensates the lack of diplomatic options with different aspects, TROY does not do so. Moreover, artificial intelligence is truly on the verge of intellectual disability at times. I have witnessed Menealus leaving Sparta, ignoring Helen and the counter-offensive of Trojan forces, and sailing across the sea to conquer a neutral settlement on Crete, resulting in him returning and trying to take back his regions. If only he was as cunning as my Odysseus...The last crucial campaign element is communing with the deities of Olympus by using food and gold in exchange for powerful passive bonuses that influence both the main map and battles. However, as it is effortless to have a lot of resources, this system becomes easily exploitable. Thus, I had the support of the gods for most of my playthrough. That becomes problematic, especially during the said battles; benefits like having a +20% range for missile units when worshipping Apollo is powerful, and the artificial intelligence is not competent to deal with you in such situations. This system is also not thought out well, as some deities punished me for no reason despite being fond of my faction. For example, Poseidon kept unleashing earthquakes on one of my islands, which even had a temple dedicated for him. I guess that gods work in mysterious ways… Even the multiplayer works in such a way, as it is in “beta” despite being released a year ago, so good luck finding a match there.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612957888Anyway, let us mote to the real-time battles, where your goal is to obliterate enemy forces or capture/defend points of interest. Even though TROY respects its Bronze Age setting by not having many cavalry units nor proper siege weapons, it does not bring anything to compensate for it. Sure, it is nice that it tries to be historically accurate, but I would expect that it would give more depth to each unit or provide more tactical possibilities, but that does not happen. Due to that, the battles feel more limiting and the same throughout the whole game, as you only upgrade to better versions of soldiers.One could argue that the special units, like Minotaurs or Cyclops, add to the variety, but they are not enough to fill that vast, empty hole. They might be useful in the first hours, but once enemies get access to elite troops, their effectivity decreases even when supported by an additional unit or two. Moreover, due to that semi-realistic approach in the “Truth Behind the Myth” mode, it is a bit weird to watch a half-naked guy with a club pretending to be cyclops while bonking everyone in the head as in the “Go to horny jail” meme.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612976912On the other hand, heroes like Achilles or my cunning Odysseus are far more enjoyable to use in the battle, and they do justice to the pompous tales, as their abilities can both increase their effectiveness or even provide bonuses for other soldiers. However, I feel that ranged heroes are a bit overpowered, as they manage to heavily damage or even wipe out enemy generals or elite units before they get close to my position.If there is something that TROY excels in, it would be its audiovisual presentation, as Greece and a part of Anatolia looks stunning, and the day and night cycle works beautifully, adding to the immersion. Additionally, it portrays Ancient Greek art at times, which is always a welcome addition. As for sounds, I already mentioned those annoying, reoccurring remarks, but the soundtrack does a fine job, underlying the overall qualities of the audiovisual.That is not merely enough, though.While I criticized TROY a lot, it does not mean that I did not have fun at times. However, that was because of the solid foundations that the Total War series already have—not because of TROY’s additions. For me, the base game is a simplistic version of its predecessors, and I do not see a single reason why would I recommend this one over those.PC Specs and PerformanceI played it with an i5 8300H, GTX 1060 6GB, and 16GB RAM, at high settings, at 30-60 frames per second, at 1920x1080 resolution. While this series tend to have optimization problems, TROY’s framerate was the most consistent for me, having fewer frame drops even during large battles, so that is a slight improvement compared to other instalments.AcknowledgementThis Danaian gift was provided for review purposes by the publisher through DitD. Thank you!Curator linkFollow my curator, Blue Lips and their Quips for more reviews like this!

Forgotten Sands is one of the best games in the Prince of Persia series, very underrated. The acrobatic platforming is amazing, mixing up powers like freezing water, making parts of the ruins reappear and rewinding time, some sequences are hard and may require flawless timing. Sadly, the story is not the best with some average combat but I do recommend this game.

Deadfall Adventures is a good fun cool blend of FPS shooting , adventure with a decent selection of puzzles. It's not a bad game by any means, but had so much potential to be great. If your looking for an Indiana Jones first person shooter look no further.

I absolutely loved Fallout New Vegas, yes its more of the same but the story is more engaging ,  I enjoyed the expanded equipment roster, tons of locations and the companions were not half bad. An excellent game, spent hours scavenging and exploring the endless amounts of loot. If you can get past the technical hurdles , it's a heckuva gaming experience.

The game has a good creepy atmosphere and is more about sneaking, investigating and researching than shooting, the save system makes many sequences very difficult. You should always try to consider shooting as a last resort. Your bullets are very limited in this game. What I loved about it was the atmosphere. Put on your headphones, shut down the lights and let the madness begin.

A lot better than I expected. The story is good, Relic really loves this universe, and it shows, the combat system works well and there was enough diversity in the weapons that it kept me interested. It gets pretty overwhelming at times with the onslaught of enemies on you. The multiplayer is pretty awesome, I recommend it.

This game is highly underrated, the story is a lot of fun, the dialogue system is great, you can play in completely different ways, both in terms of the gameplay (stealth vs going in guns blazing) and in terms of the storyline. Yes, this game worth picking up if you can get it.
